text: (upbeat music)
And I would like to thank the chemical engineers
for this great honor
and also all the nominees and sponsors.
And also I would also like to congratulate all of the other
award you saw,
it's really pleasure to be among these bright scientists.
So I love to tell you today about how imagination can spark
creativity and polymer science and play a role in our modern
technology as well. So I would begin with my journey.
I'm actually from Damascus Syria.
So Damascus is actually the oldest capitol in the world.
So it's one of the oldest
also inhibited cities in the world.
It's 9,000 year old city.
So, so I'm, I'm really,
I feel really privileged to have
been raised in that, in that city.
I also obtained my bachelor's degree in chemistry
from Damascus University back in 2005.
I also feel lucky that I lived in different countries
and very diverse skills
for working in different application areas.
Like in synthetic organic chemistry
during my Masters in actually chemistry
at King Fahd University in Saudi Arabia.
And then also working on a super molecular polymers
and nanomaterials for bone fracture treatment
during my PhD at the university of Alberta in Canada.
And then I worked on porous polymers for water purification
during my post-doctoral studies [indistinct]
at Cornell university here in the US,
which I will tell you more,
in a bit about that during this presentation.
In Arkema, I worked on acrylic radical polymerization,
I was actually part of the team that developed the first
recyclable wind turbine blade plastics,
which is now a commercial material.
Unfortunately, I'm not going to have a chance
to tell you about this cool work today.
And also currently in Dupont I'm working on
polyurethane polymers for a semiconductor chip fabrication,
which I will tell you more about it in this presentation.
So can be seen from my journey and working in
different application areas like in
health, water, energy, and electronics.
I acquired very diverse skills in different fields of
chemistry, but more importantly,
living in different countries has provided me with
really important set of skills,
like the courage to work in new areas
and learn new skills,
the ability to think creatively outside the box
all of the time,
and also the ability to adapt quickly in new cultural
and new research environments.
And more importantly,
I have a very rich imagination
that allows me to think unconventionally,
I actually consider imagination is the most important skill
needed for scientific research.
And today I'm going to give you two examples from my journey
about the importance of imagination.
One during my post-doctoral studies at Cornell
and the other is in my current working at Dupont.
So I will get started with the first example
from my post-doctoral work in which imagination
inspired a breakthrough in water purification.
So I would just like to give you a little background about
the emerging water contaminants.
These are organic micro pollutants
that we use in our daily life,
like pharmaceuticals, personal care products,
pesticides, and many other categories.
There are thousands of these molecules.
I'm just showing a few examples of them here,
but there are thousands of more molecules
that have been found in
surface and ground water supplies.
And the challenge with them
is they are not being removed effectively
by current water treatment methods.
And many of them have adverse health on ecological effects,
especially like VFAs for example, of type of pollutants.
So to, to others, this global challenge,
other researchers over the past century have explored a
variety of polymeric adsorbents
and among these are beta-cyclodextrin based polymers.
And the reason for that is because
beta-cyclodextrin is really a sugar.
It's derived from cornstarch.
So it's really sustainable material,
it's really attractive from that perspective.
And more importantly, it has unique cup-like structure
that you see in here, the single structure of it
that enables it to form a host guest
complexes with thousands of organic molecules and water.
So because of these really unique features,
basically the researchers made
hundreds of different polymers
out of cyclodextrin or for, for water purification.
I'm just showing an example of them here,
which is called epichlorohydrin cyclodextrin polymers
one of the most famous ones.
Now the challenge with all of these biggest polymers
is all of them have very low surface area.
They are basically non porous.
And as a result of their low surface area,
they absorb pollutants very slowly
over hours or even days.
I'm actually looking at literature.
I really discovered that
the reason for the low surface areas
is either the use of a slightly flexible cross linker
like epichlorohydrin for example or
and or actually,
a linkage that's like long or
relatively kind of flexible linkage [indistinct].
So I actually decided to fill this gap and
I wanted to develop the first
types of high surface area cyclodextrin polymer
for rapid water purification.
So the inspiration actually for my idea, came from,
from the bricks game.
Which I used to play a lot when I was a child.
I was really inspired that
in order to have a high surface area cyclodextrin polymer
we need like really rigid building blocks
of noncomplementary shapes.
Exactly what you see in the bricks
that inefficiently to form a network of blocks
like what you see in this image of the bricks.
So I put four criteria for the cross linker
that I was searching for.
It needs to be structurally rigid and also
linked with better cyclodextrin by
a short linkage and rapid irreversible action
to enable frustrated packing and kinetic trapping.
So basically I chose [indistinct]
as it satisfies all of the conditions.
And it's gonna react with beta-cyclodextrin
by nucleophilic aromatic substitution reaction
and develop this one step polymerization reaction
between the two monomers
using these very simple conditions and a cheap base.
And I was able to get the first high surface area
cyclodextrin polymer.
The surface area is around 250 square meter per gram.
As a result of that,
this polymer can sequester thousands of
organic molecules in water almost instantaneously,
like you see in the blue trace here
in just a couple of seconds.
Like the commercial water filters
based on activated carbons or
even a previous beta-cyclodextrin polymers
which takes a much longer time.
In addition,
this polymer can be recycled several times
using very simple conditions at a good temperature.
So this imagination inspired work
really led to a new line of research.
We did this stuff and several students
continued this work on a bet on it.
they really developed several new versions
of this polymer for water air purification.
And in addition, this polymer also
inspired many researchers around the world
as our original report in nature,
got cited over 1000 times in less than five years.
And also we had several heightened publications
and also granted patents worldwide.
So this work also laid the groundwork for a startup company
called Cyclopure, which was chosen by
Chemical and Engineering News
as one of the top ten startups in 2019.
And also it commercialized beta-cyclodextrin purification.
So just to really show us how imagination can be really
impactful and it can really, you know,
help us solve some of the societal problems
that we currently have.
So I would like now to switch gears and think about the
second example in my current work in Dupont,
in which imagination plays a role
electronic chip fabrication.
So as we know,
electronic chips are the heart and the brain of
different electronic devices that
we use in our daily life.
Really they are an essential part of
our modern technology nowadays.
So electronic chips are made on silicon wafers that
you see in the bottom left.
Each wafer contains hundreds of chips,
which are diced after the fabrication process.
Now, if we magnify and look closely
at the surface of these chips
we can see the actual circuitry containing a very
complicated network of interconnected micro wires
of different metals and also semiconductor features.
Which can be as small as a few nanometers in size.
If we look at the cross section of the chip,
we can see multiple layers of
different metals and semiconductors.
In some cases we can have as many as thirty layers in total.
Now each layer must be completely flattened before
we deposit the next layer.
This flattening is made by a process called
chemical/mechanical planarization or CMP.
So basically different CMP processes are applied
throughout the chip fabrication process.
So just to show how important CMP is,
if you look at this top right image
that's where if you try to make the chip without CMP,
basically you get a useless chip.
You can't use it for any device [indistict] function.
So CMP is really what enables us to really accurately
print the microscape features on the chip.
It's essential to modern electronics.
Here's the CMP machine
and the five main components of it.
The wafer is actually mounted
actually facing downwards on the wafer carrier head
that you see in there and is pushed
against the polishing pad.
Now, both the pad and the wafer
rotate in the same direction but at different speeds.
And also at the same time,
a slurry is dispensed through the slurry dispenser.
Now, the slurry is a chemically active solution
that contains abrasive microparticles.
Now, chemical activity of the slurry
enables the chemical polishing,
whereas the abrasive particles and
the polishing part enable the mechanical polishing.
Also, we have a conditioner that's
pressed against the pad
to create a rough surface texture
to enable the mechanical polishing as well.
Actually, Dupont is one of the industry leaders
in high quality materials for CMP,
especially polishing pads and also slurries,
and it continues to innovate
to meet the new industry needs.
Just to appreciate the complexity of CMP and
the importance of imagination in this process
here I'm showing the total number of variables
within each of the five components of CMP.
You can see how many variables we have on,
there's also large space within each of these variables.
So this process is extremely complicated
and it's not a well understood.
Any variation with any of these variables can
impact the interface processes between the wafer,
the pad and the slurry.
You can see at the interface
also the slurry abrasive particles in blue
and also these features on the pad
which are called the asperities
and they are created by the conditioning process,
they are in the micron dimensions.
Now, the chemistry and the physics at this interface,
like the hydrodynamic state, the friction,
the sheer layer thickness, or the contact area,
other phenomena as well.
It dictates the polishing output parameters
in each of these six different categories,
which are also very complicated and it's very difficult to
balance all of them or even deconvolute them to achieve
the desired performance in all of them.
So that's why imagination is
really essential to visualize and hypothesize
how long, which input variables can impact
the interfacial processes and how the interfacial processes
impact or dictate the polishing output parameters.
So imagination is really the core
and the driver of our research in CMP.
By the way,
the polishing output parameter
is not only influenced on the,
on the efficiency of the fabrication process,
but also on the semiconductor on the performance
of the semiconductor itself.
So now, [indistinct]
Since my research focuses on this area,
CMP pads are made polyurethane block called polymers.
And as we know, polyurethanes are very versatile polymers
consisting mainly of three parts.
So we have the polyol chain in red here [indistinct]
to form what's called the soft segments.
And we have the, [indistinct]
in blue and the chain extended in green,
which crystallized on what's called the hard domains.
Now the choice of these three components dictate the
thermo mechanical properties
and the viscoelastic properties of these pads.
In addition, we can have also multiple components
within each of these categories,
like more than one poly or more than chain extender.
So the formulation space of CMP pads is huge.
And again, that's why imagination is also really important
to correlate between structural-like variations
and the resulting properties of these pads.
In addition, also we add blowing agents
to create pores in the pad.
So basically CMP pads are hard foams,
and you can see on the right image
that we have also different patterns and designs.
So different pads also to,
to meet a wide variety of application
and performance requirements.
Just here to show quickly how we do research in CMP pads.
So we begin with ideation and hypothesis.
Imagination actually is really the driver to
ideation the hypothesis. We imagine how,
and which input variables can help us achieve the output
parameters that our customers are looking for.
And then we'll proceed to more advanced steps like
DOE design, afforded mutation screening,
making and evaluating polishing pads
and then reevaluating hypothesis if we need.
Once we identify promising candidates,
we proceed more advanced steps like scaling up
on customer sampling.
So imagination is really the driver of our CMP pads.
I'm not going to dig farther into my actual research
you know, at Dupont, but I would to say that actually
a new family of pads
that I co invented
is expected to got to market
next year, which I'm really happy about.
So I'd like to end my talk
with a really nice quote form Albert Einstein,
which I really believe in,
I think it's really important message about,
about imagination, I'm going to read it out loud.
Imagination is more important than knowledge
for knowledge is limited to all we know how to understand,
while imagination embraces the entire world
and all there ever will be to know and understand.
I think this is really powerful,
and it really shows how important imagination is
in scientific research, so keep imagining.
I would like to thank the key influencers
around my, you know, my journey.
I really thank all of them,
from each of these great people
I learned at least something
that contributed to who I am now.
So I thank all of them for their input,
for their contribution
and for their guidance along my way.
And I would also like to thank my family,

And also I would like to thank all of my colleagues,
all of these stages also for their help
and support on my work and on my studies,
I would like to thank you for attention and [indistinct].
Take any question now. Thank you.

I wanted to ask you, you've worked on
like a really broad range of problems,
and I was wondering
how do you approach a problem in an area
that you're unfamiliar with?
So the first thing,
so if the area is really outside
my expertise, I stuck with books.
So it's really great.
So I usually choose books that are not older than
two years old, maybe.
So I try to read recent books about the particular area.
And then I go to usually like review articles,
because review articles are really big overview
of the fields, usually, and the recent advances in it.
And then I go to the research papers
and dig farther and farther into
kind of the most recent advances in that particular area.
But these are the steps that I usually take
if the area is not that far from what I know about,
I start with reviews, not books, basically,
but for example, when I work on polyurethane in Dupont,
I start with books because
semiconductors were very new to me.
Polyurethane, I've never worked on polyurethane
so I start with books.
So that's a particular example.
Yeah.
